text: Monzo have just decided to close my account I use to withdraw my winnings, after asking me some questions. Can anyone recommend a bank who aren’t bothered by frequent deposits from Betfair?

elements.text: Monzo have just decided to close my account I use to withdraw my winnings, after asking me some questions. Can anyone recommend a bank who
aren’t
bothered by frequent deposits from Betfair?

text: Betfair -> PayPal -> bank

elements.text: Betfair -> PayPal -> bank

text: Ah, hadn’t thought of that. PayPal are pretty chilled then?

elements.text: Ah,
hadn’t
thought of that. PayPal are pretty chilled then?

text: PayPal do have an extended ID check at a certain yearly usage limit. Had a big slots win once (over 2k) and withdrew to PayPal. Account locked pending enhanced checks. Took over a week. Just be aware. If you've already been through that probably ok. Same as if they've ditched those checks as it was about 8 years ago

text: Have people had problems with the more traditional banks? I've been withdrawing for years to a well known high street bank and have had no issues.

text: What questions did Monzo ask?

elements.text: What questions did Monzo ask?

text: Or rather, was the closure related to withdrawals?

elements.text: Or rather, was the closure related to withdrawals?

text: They asked for a statement from my main bank that I send my winnings to every month, why I was sending money to Trading212 (a low cost broker) and why I was sending some money to my girlfriend each month and what our relationship is.

elements.text: They asked for a statement from my main bank that I send my winnings to every month, why I was sending money to Trading212 (a low cost broker) and why I was sending some money to my girlfriend each month and what our relationship is.

text: Yeah quite odd. I guess they may not have enough resources to care if you're a false positive or not

elements.text: Yeah quite odd. I guess they may not have enough resources to care if you're a false positive or not

text: If you are withdrawing money from a betting operator and then dispersing it into another bank account in your name, a trading account, and another person's name, and have no other activity (like using the account to buy things), Monzo will not make money from your account. They make money from you holding money there and using your debit card, or having direct debits (as the merchant pays a small fee). They will also likely consider your behaviour to be similar to some money launderers. Regs are such that they'd probably rather just be rid of a slightly suspect loss-making account than deal with it.

elements.text: If you are withdrawing money from a betting operator and then dispersing it into another bank account in your name, a trading account, and another person's name, and have no other activity (like using the account to buy things), Monzo will not make money from your account. They make money from you holding money there and using your debit card, or having direct debits (as the merchant pays a small fee). They will also likely consider your behaviour to be similar to some money launderers. Regs are such that they'd probably rather just be rid of a slightly suspect loss-making account than deal with it.

text: Other banks are ~fine~ more experienced with ~money launderers and criminals~ independently minded entrepreneurs though. NatWest, Barclays, HSBC, all ~have blood on their hands historically~ should welcome your custom.

text: Of course we know this isn't laundering. It's such an exceptionally rare activity though (money normally goes only one way with betting operators), it's always going to be a little hard to convince a regular customer service agent that while it walks like a money laundering duck and talks like a money laundering duck, it's actually legit...

text: Is there any reason you want to hide gambling wins being deposited directly to your account? Because lenders will want to query where that comes from too possibly (and solicitors if buying property).

text: It's strange that being outside of tax and legitimacy is because of a 100 year old case defining us a skillful addicts.   <https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/business-income-manual/bim22017|https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/business-income-manual/bim22017>

text: An article in the Christmas edition of the Economist that I think will appeal to many here: <https://archive.is/Ltan5>

attachments.fallback: archive.is: How much happiness does money buy?
attachments.title: How much happiness does money buy?

elements.text: An article in the Christmas edition of the Economist that I think will appeal to many here:

text: Being able to maximally spend time with family much

elements.text: Being able to maximally spend time with family much

text: I actually think there's an angle in here about over-betting. I think people are prone to betting more than they should because of relative utility.

elements.text: I actually think there's an angle in here about over-betting. I think people are prone to betting more than they should because of relative utility.

text: In the same issue there is a tragic letters page contribution from a woman whose son committed suicide after being preyed on by US books "VIP'ing" him into a $10k NHL bet that he chased. Having red misted myself years ago, I honestly think it's all about trying to buy happiness, and so I don't have a problem with spending limits myself. All part of the same mix.

elements.text: In the same issue there is a tragic letters page contribution from a woman whose son committed suicide after being preyed on by US books "VIP'ing" him into a $10k NHL bet that he chased. Having red misted myself years ago, I honestly think it's all about trying to buy happiness, and so I don't have a problem with spending limits myself. All part of the same mix.

text: That article focuses on a Merton (yes, him), paper on using a constant relative risk-aversion utility function. I suspect most of us would have a different utility function to the general population, but also very different to most hobby gamblers.
